reviewText:
Before I get into the game's problems, I would like to say what's good about it. Shooting games where you fight giant insects is a rarity, so points for a concept that hasn't been explored much. The game aslo has a grand sense of scale, with huge buildings getting destroyed as collateral in the fights and huge boss-type foes that are taller than lots of the buildings themselves. It also usually introduces a new enemy or a new vehicle every mission (at least for a while). Although far from a perfectly implemented, the game also gives the player several classes with their own abilities, and the ability to change your gun loadout between missions.

However, this game has a number of problems. First, it is extremely repetitive. There is very little variance in mission objectives. It's always go here, kill all the constantly spawning enemies, repeat. There's little in terms of varied environments; Where you are on the map has almost no effect on how any given situation is approached. Combat is also repetitive, with waves and waves of the same four enemy types with an occasional bullet sponge boss. Waves of enemies tend to go on for entirely too long, and I found myself wishing for a change of scenery halfway through most of the firefights. As mentioned, most of the bosses are bullet sponges, not particularly difficult to defeat, but it takes a very very long time. Only occasionally are boss battles fun.

The system of armor classes and unlockable weapons is a nice thought, but it is poorly implemented. Weapons can be found on the battlefield, usually after killing some boss monster. However, weapons are also divided into tiers, and even after collected can only be unlocked via leveling up the armor class that uses said weapon. The problem with this is that it can take too long to level up. If you change your armors for the sake of varying the gameplay, level ups are few and far in between, so the weapons you pick up become unused, and the enemies become increasingly durable (the game uses skin swapped versions of some enemies with more health later in the game). Either the game becomes repetitive because it gradually  takes more time to kill enemies or it becomes repetitive by sticking to the same class.

Overall, the game has some good ideas, but most are not very well implemented. Some people might find enjoyment from this game, but the giant bug novelty isn't enough to salvage the gameplay

First and foremost, the controls are a little jenky. Plain and simple. They do not always respond the way you want to, however, they are not terrible. The teammate A.I. is horrible. In a game where you are getting swamped left and right literally hundreds, if not more, enemies at once, your teammates ability to hold their own is very important... and the A.I. completely drops the ball. They are inaccurate, will just stand there soaking up damage and dying a quick death and also, for some reason, seem to have an inability to revive you if you fall in battle. This is especially problematic in major boss battles where you are getting swamped with 2 or more boss enemies and the usual barrage of hundreds of normal enemies and when there are few wide spread checkpoints in the level.

All this being said however, the game is unusually fun and entertaining despite these issues. There is something gratifying each time you make an enemy go splat and a great sense of accomplishment when you do actually complete a level. The charterer leveling system is fulfilling as well. Each tier unlocks new weapons, deployables and upgrades, which in turn makes playing single player more enjoyable and less frustrating. The game really shines in co-op mode however and makes most of the technical issues much more bearable. The story is really not anything that special. It is pretty much just an excuse to blow away tons of abnormally large insects, arachnids and aliens... which is just fine as long as you know what you are getting into.

Final verdict: Despite the technical flaws the game is a fun kill fest that is worth the minimal money it costs.  4/5 stars

sorry guys.  i really wanted to like this game.  i mean i REALLY REALLY wanted to like this game.  i have been an EDF fan since GDF days.  i thought, how hard could it really be to make an EDF game?  even i know the formula, these developers surely couldn't have messed it up.

how to make EDF game

1. fill stupidly large area with large amounts of generic destructible objects, i.e. rocks, buildings, etc.
2. put bugs or robots or aliens or something on the map - lots of them, like wayyyy too many
3. make tons of weapons of radically varying levels of actual usefulness and cram them in
4. create mission scenarios that are all as vague as humanly possible cuz they are all the exact same: kill everything
5. crank all engine physics up into the red, then do it again 2x for good measure

just like that, i've made a good EDF game.  so what went wrong here?

EDF is not an action 3rd person shooter series.  it is sooo slow, missions are mind-numbingly long, it's repetitive beyond all reason and you never really feel like you've made any progress in the games because nothing has changed.  you're doing the exact same thing you were 2 missions ago.  literally - nothing has changed.  it has a heavy hypnotic, zen-like quality to it - clearing a massive map is simple but tedious, and there is a special kind of old school arcade pleasure in glancing at your minimap occassionally to see the field of red dots slowly thin.

in insect armageddon, they have forgone that slower pace, and put in it's place a weird checkpoint system where enemies come in individual waves.  they made a decision to have the bodies vaporize" instead of just explode into the distance - a damn shame considering the gonzo physics has always been a huge draw for these games.  the cheeky humor is intact

reviewText: I really wanted to be able to give this one a positive review. Even with the rose-tinted glasses of having played and immensely enjoyed the original EDF. The first had its good and bad points, but it was the good points that salvaged the game's bad ones. Yes, repetative gameplay is pretty much the staple of this series, but it never got too boring because of the campy, B-horror tone, the hilarious enemy physics (dead ants bouncing gloriously into the heavens) and the scale and variety of the creatures.\n\nUnfortunately, IA seems to have decided to do away with all that. Gone is the humor. Replaced with a more serious (but still somehow silly) gritty approach. Gone are the physics and the scale. Gone is the variety (well, you get some variety...if you like Spider Type A, B, C. Mix that up with Bee Type A, B, C, etc.). It's nice to have larger maps to explore, but they're hardly inventive or varied enough.  Overall, it was a pretty dissapointing experience.

reviewText:
This is a tricky one. After my first 15 hours, I got bored and wrote a rather bad review. However, after dusting the game out of forgotten diskspaces for a second time, I actually found it rather enjoyable and when I got my two gaming buddies to get it, it turned into a blast. (Literally)

So, let's take a look at the game itself, shall we:
EDF is a franchise that was actually around a bit longer, but usually console-exclusive. EDF:IA is (afaik) the sole PC-avaible title of the franchise.
The original franchise relies on 'So bad it's good again'-style of voice acting, cinematics, plot and really doesn't try to take itself too seriously. Combine that with a full-arcade 'omg shoot the aliens' exploding spamfest, and you got a rough draw of what EDF does.
This specific instance of the instance is, as mentioned, the only PC title and, sadly, wasn't developed by the original developers, but by a foreign group. And many fans complain that EDF:IA is nowhere near as good as any of the old titles and a bad joke compared to EDF:2025 (one of the more recent titles).

EDF:IA itself is straight forward: Aliens invade Earth, you are an elite soldier group with absurd weapons utilizing endless ammo, and now fight your way through a 15-mission campaign. Doing so, you unlock more and more powerful weapons, till killing the enemies actually becomes a sidequest next to leveling the entire battlefield. Because that is what you can literally do: Level the (exclusive) city-maps to a heap of rubble. And damn, that's satisfying. Especially because your teammate is a jettrooper direly trying to get into a high spot.
As with it's ancestors, the main progression point of EDF:IA lies in unlocking new weapons for the four playable classes. Not that every class comes with 5-6 weapon categories, with dozens of (often unique) weapons each, from which you can bring exactly 2 to each mission.
Standard assault rifles? Sure. SMG's for the Tac Officer? Jep. Rocket Launchers? Duh! BIG rocket launchers? Too.
Tactical Nuclear missile launchers which fires rockets slower then a hulking heavy? Included. Giant multi-missile 8-tuble super-sized nuclear flare ANTI-AIR rockets? Je, this game goes silly at times.

Of course, the game DOES have a fair number of downpoints: First off, it's limited campaign. You get one campaign of 15 missions, which maybe cover ~3-5 hours. Then you get a 'Campaign Remix' which plays on the same maps, but with different objectives and enemy groupings. And lastly a rather crude Survival mode. The game offers 3 difficulty degrees which SEVERELY ramp up said difficulty: On Normal, you have to put effort into actually dieing. On Hard, you will despare in the first mission because those tiny ant enemies suddenly survive your best rocket launchers and actually kill you in a few hits. On Inferno... let's say I didn't yet make it into Inferno.
Creativity in enemy design is another weak suit of the game: You get Ants. Spiders. Ticks. Wasps. Robots. Then you get Robot Ants, Robot Spiders, Robot Wasps. And another Robot Spider. The game tries to compensate for that by making jokes via the radio. Hey intel

reviewText:
This game is a lot better than it should be. It doesn't really excel in anything, but it's just plain fun. The campaign mode doesn't offer a lot of variety. You go around killing bugs, planting the occasional bomb, reaching rendezvous points and so on, with the game throwing in a new kind of bug to shoot every now and then.

The game's sense of humour will make you grin at times with jokes that show that it's not taking itself too seriously. The variety of weapons is quite decent and it will take you a while to get all the upgrades for each class. It's a lot of fun to see how much damage you can to when you get a new piece of equipment! The pace of the game is intense at times and it's really fun to run through seemingly endless hoards of bugs while blasting at your heart's content.

To sum things up. This game is quite shallow and repetitive, but I found myself coming back for more for quite a while. I'd recommend this game to anyone who enjoys blasting gigantic bugs with a variety of futuristic weapons just for the heck of it.

PROS:

-alien units are well designed and animated

CONS:

-graphics are a tad bland and levels generally look all the same

-unremarkable voice acting

-gameplay is overall simple and boils down to going from point A to B shooting everything that moves

-some enemy waves last a bit too long

-no tutorial whatsoever, thankfully it's easy to pick up and any doubts can be cleared by looking up a FAQ

-a bit on the short side

-leveling up armors takes quite a long time, you'll have to grind missions once you're done with the campaign or simply replay it selecting a higher difficulty

Being entirely new to the series, I don't quite know how Insect Armageddon stacks up to the other Earth Defense Force titles. On its own, however, I believe it to be a solid game, doing exactly what it sets out to in a more than playable fashion.

Even Serious Sam has a difficult time comparing to the sheer scale of Earth Defense Force's battles, where the smallest of enemies is at least the size of the player and the largest stand as tall as an apartment building. With hordes in excess of hundreds at almost every turn and the player's arsenal constantly increasing in shock value and near-absurdity, things can get a bit more than hectic.

In terms of variety, EDF is a mixed bag. Much of the combat begins to drag on as the game enters the later stages of the oddly short campaign - doable in roughly seven hours by one's lonesome - as the relatively limited selection of enemies begins to show through.
In terms of weapon and playstyle variety, however, I would draw a considerable amount of comparisons to Borderlands. There are an enormous amount of interesting weapons, ranging from run-of-the-mill assault rifles to airburst missiles that rain smaller warheads down on their targets after detonation. Four different classes, such as the unmatchably maneuverable Jet and the nigh-unkillable Battle, give good options for players of all persuasions.

Graphically, the game is another toss-up. The streets of the cities feel somewhat empty and undetailed and, while undoubtedly pretty to watch and true game-changers for the battlefield environment, the collapse of buildings leaves much to be desired in their wake. Skyscrapers end up leaving little but a neatly-confined pile of rubble, cars explode piecelessly, and the thousands of enemies slaughtered in the campaign leave little but a brief, fading corpse - which, humorously, is often sent hurtling into space by some of the higher tier weapons.
However, much of the model work is definitely up to par, and while the lack of graphical options and locked framerate makes the game feel much like a console port, the game runs flawlessly.

Third party support, unfortunately, seems to be nonexistent. There's not much else to be said here; unless I've simply failed to find it, there's no possibility of a modding community for any but the most die-hard fans.

In the end, at its cheap price point of $10 USD, it'd be hard to turn this game down. If you're looking for something with longevity, that price point may be less exciting. Even still, for someone looking for a quick, frantic, larger-than-life game that charmingly follows every cliché in alien invasion movies, this is most definitely the game to be sought.

Earth Defense Force is a third person shooter pitting you against hordes of alien invaders, said invaders are using giant robots and huge bio-enginereed insects to invade our world:  it's up to you to stop them in the 15 campaign missions.

PROS:

-alien units are well designed and animated

-intense, frantic combat against hordes of insects and robots

-most of the environment can be destroyed, cars blow up and buildings crumble to dust when hit with rockets: this adds a slight strategic layer to things cause doing so increases your line of sight (at the cost of cover) and gives the alien insects less surfaces to crawl on

-dialogue is generally funny, the game really doesn't take itself seriously with soldiers joking and abesnt-minded intel officers taking their time to explain how to beat a boss

-a good amount of armors and weapons to unlock and level up

-very fun when played in coop

-when not playing coop AI companions are quite competent and generally quite effective

CONS:

-graphics are a tad bland and levels generally look all the same

-unremarkable voice acting

-gameplay is overall simple and boils down to going from point A to B shooting everything that moves

-some enemy waves last a bit too long

-no tutorial whatsoever, thankfully it's easy to pick up and any doubts can be cleared by looking up a FAQ

-a bit on the short side

-leveling up armors takes quite a long time, you'll have to grind missions once you're done with the campaign or simply replay it selecting a higher difficulty

EDF comes out as a straightforward game that offers plenty of mindless fun, shooting tons of enemies and leveling the city using the various over the top weapons at your disposal is truly enjoyable.
There's not much of a story, the characters are cliched and the ending feels hurried but the fact is the game isn't really interested in that stuff: what it wants is to offer you an huge b-movie inspired alien armada-and a few bosses-to blow up alone or with friends: and it does so really well.

I'm not sure the game has alot of staying power once it's done, there's a campaign remix mode that adds different foes and ups the ante a bit but it doesn't really change things much, so you'll have to play survival with friends or just grind campaign missions again to level up everything.

At its sale price of 3 bucks EDF is a really fun albeit simple and short game: if you're into third person shooters and like its campy b-movie style it will not let you down.

A fun game to pick up and play for a few hours at a time, this shooter places you into a very well scripted b-movie vibe millitary shooter.(Playtime does not reflect my substantial offline time commitment)

Obviously you fight giant bugs and robot bugs in the streets of New Detroit with either two generic NPC soliders who don't really get a chance to show you much of thier personality except through the generic chatter they exchange during missions. Or you can replace the NPC's with online players (a much more helpful prospect, the NPCs are tragically underprepared for air combat). While the game advances or the waves of survival continue the types and abilities in enemies introdces new ways the enemy tries to bring the battle to you. The enemy types range from simplistic, to ludicrous health walls, or in the case of most flying enemies extremely challenging targets unless you are carrying the right weapons.

Luckily the game gives you a massive list of weapons to choose from as you play through and unlock more weapons with interesting differences like specific weapon spreads, tracking, DOT and explosion radius. These all may sound like basic shooter fare, but when coupled with the class abilities for each armor (which each have thier own weapon classes used and level up seperately) makes the experience drastically different for each armor. Wether you fly around with the jetpack, taking carefully aimed sniper shots (or rain death with a rocket launcher) from far above the battlefield, or use the tactical armor to drop turrets to add another gun while blasting with your weapon of choice, or play with the largest weapon selection with the solider or use the heavy to deliver maximum firepower to the enemy.

Unfortunately after beating the main campaign, there story remains totally static, difficulty increases simply give enemies more health, even in the Game + mode the only difference is that enemy types are changed so advanced enemies show up earlier than normal. This makes going back into the story (the only way to advance armor level since survival uses a set level core trooper armor) something of a chore, but with a few friends playing for fun it becomes more enjoyable. Survival is a fun distraction, but without any advancement beyond a number of waves it can become stale once you stop trying out new weapons (especially since you can't unlock new weapons or amor levels in survival) and maps.

All in All: I really like this game on principal, my first playthrough solo was a huge blast, but I regretably didn't get as much out of subsequent returns to the battlefields of New Detroit. Initial Playthrough: 9/10 (only the prolongued sequences of me trying to shoot down aircraft with a shotgun or gernade launcher prevented the ten). Subsequent Playthrough: 6/10 Man.... it just feels grindy once I change to a new armor... and the NPC playstyle only compounds this issue.

Final score: 8/10

Do you remember when you were 8 years old and would spend the day in your backyard with a magnifying glass, relishing in the wanton slaughter of thousands of ants?
Remember when you visited your best friend in a rural area when he had a rat problem and took full advantage of the firepower they had within the residence?
Remember Battlefront 2?

Enjoy the humorous (Though limited) dialogue of the best damn AI squadmates you'll ever find outside of Republic Commando. Chuckle as the pilot regails you with calm, nearly deadpan humor despite constantly being a few seconds away from death by flying car, robot wasp, or giant bomb at any given time.
On top of all that, SAVE THE ♥♥♥♥ING WORLD!!!
